Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Cross-layer optimization in Cognitive Radio Networks in the Physical interference model based on SINR constraints: Algorithmic Foundations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most significant recent advances in wireless networks is the
Cognitive Radio Network (CRN), which can allow unlicensed (or secondary) users to access spectrum bands allocated to licensed (primary) users, without disrupting their performance.
Since many licensed spectrum bands have been found to be greatly underutilized,
CRNs can potentially enhance the spectrum usage significantly.
The basic principle underlying CRNs is to first sense the spectrum usage by primary users, and then allocate power levels and channels opportunistically to the secondary users, so that the interference levels at primary users are within an acceptable threshold. Most theoretical analyses of protocols in such networks use disk/graph based approximations (in which "close-by" links cannot transmit simultaneously) to model wireless interference; however, these are inadequate and can lead to infeasible solutions with unacceptable interference levels at the primary users.

The goal of this proposal is to examine the theoretical foundations of cross-layer optimization in Cognitive Radio Networks in the Physical interference model, which is considered a much better approximation of interference than disk based models. The results of this proposal will contribute to the theoretical underpinnings of the broader area of wireless networks, not just the application of CRN, because of the central role interference plays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cognitive Radio Networks allow wireless networks to operate with dynamic 
channel and power control, which makes them more flexible on one hand, 
but more challenging to operate optimally, on the other hand. The goal of 
this project was to develop the algorithmic foundations for basic problems 
such as scheduling, topology control and throughput maximization. This 
involves two main challenges. The first is interference, which determines 
which links can transmit simultaneously. In this project, we have focused 
on the Physical interference model based on SINR constraints, which has 
been found to be much more realistic than earlier graph based models. 
The second major challenge is that these problems involve cross-layer 
constraints from different layers in the protocol stack, specifically, the 
physical, MAC routing and transport layers. Typically, protocols have been 
designed and optimized for specific layers. However, combining optimal 
protocols for different layers does not lead to optimal performance overall.  In this project, we have studied a unified framework to address both these 
challenges, based on convex programming and multi-commodity flows in 
networks. Our framework provides a natural way to incorporate constraints 
from multiple layers, leading to a new approach for power control, scheduling, 
topology control and throughput capacity optimization. Our framework also 
enables SINR constraints to be incorporated in the Physical layer.  The constraints 
yield both lower and upper bounds on the capacity region, allowing us to obtain 
rigorous algorithmic results with provable performance guarantees.  Since wireless networks are inherently decentralized, algorithms for scheduling 
need to be distributed.  Designing such algorithms becomes challenging in the 
SINR model of interference, because of its non-local nature. We have developed 
novel algorithmic techniques for distributed scheduling in the SINR model.  Our 
algorithms crucially use characteristics of wireless radio devices, specifically, 
physical carrier sensing and the distributed decisions are made based on the 
Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI). We find that the complexity of the 
distributed algorithms depends crucially on the specific wireless technologies that 
are used, laying the foundations for distributed algorithms for other problems in 
this model.  We have further developed these techniques for distributed construction
of well connected topologies and maximizing the total throughput.   Finally, we found that network structure and traffic characteristics have a significant 
impact on the performance.  Our research has also led naturally to the problems of 
better modeling of realistic networks and mobility at urban scale.
